level.text: CFSA may issue a temporary license to operate a foster home only if:
The applicant is kin to each foster child who would be placed in her or his home;
The applicant has submitted an application for a license to operate a foster home;
The applicant has:
Received a satisfactory criminal records check from the Interstate Identification Index System of the National Crime Information Center (III);
Applied for a criminal records check in accordance with § 6008 of this Chapter;
Complied with the requirements of § 6009 of this Chapter concerning the Child Protection Register check;
Received a satisfactory safety assessment of the prospective foster home; and
Demonstrated the willingness and ability to provide a safe and secure environment for a foster child;
All individuals eighteen (18) years of age or older residing in the prospective foster home have:
Received a satisfactory criminal records check from the III;
Applied for a criminal records check in accordance with § 6008 of this Chapter; and
Complied with the requirements of § 6009 of this Chapter concerning the Child Protection Register check;
There exist exigent circumstances as set forth in § 6027.2 of this Chapter; and
A lead-based paint certificate has been obtained indicating no risk from lead-based paint for a home built before March 1, 1978, in which a foster child under six (6) years of age may be placed.
Exigent circumstances exist if a child who would be placed in the home if it had a temporary license:
Must be removed from her or his home immediately because of suspected or supported child abuse or neglect;
Is in CFSA’s custody and must be removed from her or his placement immediately; or
Has been removed from her or his home because of child abuse and neglect; and
A petition alleging neglect of the child has been filed before the Family Division of the Superior Court of the District of Columbia pursuant to D.C. Official Code § 16-2305; and
A disposition of the neglect petition pursuant to D.C. Official Code § 16-2320 has not yet occurred.
An applicant is kin to a foster child if the applicant is:
At least 21 years of age; and
Either:
A relative of the foster child by blood, marriage, or adoption; or

Identified by a relative of the foster child by blood, marriage, or adoption, in a sworn affidavit, to have close personal or emotional ties with the foster child or the foster child’s family, which pre-dated the foster child’s placement with the individual.
A temporary license:
Permits a foster home to operate prior to issuance of an annual license and while the foster parent(s) attempts to satisfy the requirements for a license; and
Expires in one hundred fifty (150) days from the date of the temporary license.
A temporary license may be renewed once and for no more than ninety (90) days if the:
Applicant is making a good faith effort to comply with all elements of the foster home licensing process as set forth in this Chapter;
Renewal is needed to complete the licensing process;
Licensing process is not completed for a reason that is beyond the control of the applicant; and
Applicant has otherwise complied with the requirements of this Chapter.
A temporary licensee under this section shall actively and promptly take all steps required for full licensure under this Chapter.
A foster child who is not kin to the applicant may not be placed in a foster home that has a temporary license.

Except as specifically set forth in § 6027, all sections of this Chapter shall apply to a foster parent or foster home that has a temporary license except that the denial of a temporary license shall not be grounds for an appeal pursuant to § 6032 of a temporary license shall not be grounds for an appeal pursuant to § 6032 of this Chapter.
